channel.title: Late Night Live - Full program podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: From razor-sharp analysis of current events to the hottest debates in politics, science, philosophy and culture, Late Night Live puts you firmly in the big picture.
channel.description: From razor-sharp analysis of current events to the hottest debates in politics, science, philosophy and culture, Late Night Live puts you firmly in the big picture.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020, Australian Broadcasting Corporation. All Rights Reserved.
channel.itunes:author: ABC Radio
channel.itunes:summary: From razor-sharp analysis of current events to the hottest debates in politics, science, philosophy and culture, Late Night Live puts you firmly in the big picture.

item.title: Jung Chang and Kate McClymont
item.itunes:subtitle: Jung Chang on the Soong sisters and Kate McClymont on the murder of Michael McGurk
item.description: Jung Chang on the Soong sisters and Kate McClymont on the murder of Michael McGurk

media:group.media:description: Ei-ling Soong, May-ling Soong and Ching-ling Soong in Chunking, 1940.

item.title: Lord Tughendat's library and the Future Library
item.itunes:subtitle: Christopher Tughendat has written a history of Britain through its literature and we find out about the wonderful and hopeful future library.
item.description: Christopher Tughendat has written a history of Britain through its literature and we find out about the wonderful and hopeful future library.

media:group.media:description: Margaret Atwood, the first author to write a book for the Future Library, is pictured here with Scottish artist Katie Paterson deep in the Nordmarka forest near Oslo.

item.title: Happy Birthday Phillip
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Fidler asks Phillip Adams the questions in his 80th birthday special.
item.description: Richard Fidler asks Phillip Adams the questions in his 80th birthday special.

item.title: The adventures of Di Morrissey
item.itunes:subtitle: Di Morrissey has come full circle coming back to her birth place and journalistic roots.
item.description: Di Morrissey has come full circle coming back to her birth place and journalistic roots.

item.title: Politicised convicts; Decoding Australia's first dictionary
item.itunes:subtitle: Australia's convicts were highly politicised - both those who were sent as political prisoners, and the ordinary convicts who were soon organising and agitating against unfair work requirements.
item.description: Australia's convicts were highly politicised - both those who were sent as political prisoners, and the ordinary convicts who were soon organising and agitating against unfair work requirements.

media:group.media:description: William Cuffay, the son of a West Indian slave and an English woman, campaigned in England for an eight hour day. He was sentenced to 21 years in Van Diemen's Land, for 'conspiring to levy a war' against Queen Victoria.

item.title: Tim Costello: Faith and fear
item.itunes:subtitle: Tim Costello chats about faith, fear and politics.
item.description: Tim Costello chats about faith, fear and politics.

item.title: Virginia Hall: WW2 Master spy; Richard Sorge: master spy
item.itunes:subtitle: Virginia Hall managed to convince both UK and US spy agencies to send her into France during WW2, despite the fact she was a woman and an amputee. The reports from Russian spy Richard Sorge back to Moscow were critical in determining the outcome of WW2.
item.description: Virginia Hall managed to convince both UK and US spy agencies to send her into France during WW2, despite the fact she was a woman and an amputee. The reports from Russian spy Richard Sorge back to Moscow were critical in determining the outcome of WW2.

media:group.media:description: Virginia Hall worked with the resistance in France during WW2.

item.title: Louise Adler: Life and learning
item.itunes:subtitle: Louise Adler shares her thought on life with Phillip Adams
item.description: Louise Adler shares her thought on life with Phillip Adams

item.title: Marcia Langton
item.itunes:subtitle: Marcia Langton on life's detours.
item.description: Marcia Langton on life's detours.

item.title: Dorian Lynskey on 1984 and Tony Rinaudo on forest making
item.itunes:subtitle: Dorian Lynskey on the 70th anniversary of 1984 and Tony Rinaudo on how to make forests.
item.description: Dorian Lynskey on the 70th anniversary of 1984 and Tony Rinaudo on how to make forests.

media:group.media:description: A mural of George Orwell in the English town of Southwold referencing a quote from the writer's prescient novel '1984' and his wartime work at the BBC.

item.title: Robyn Archer and Sisonke Msimang on Winne Mandela
item.itunes:subtitle: Robyn Archer looks back on her life of cabaret and Sisonke Msimang has an honest look at the life of Winnie Mandela.
item.description: Robyn Archer looks back on her life of cabaret and Sisonke Msimang has an honest look at the life of Winnie Mandela.

media:group.media:description: Robyn Archer, performer, festival director and mentor

item.title: Elena Kats-Chernin
item.itunes:subtitle: Where does Elena Kats-Chernin's music come from?
item.description: Where does Elena Kats-Chernin's music come from?

item.title: What do fossils, babies and Einstein tell us about the way our brains have evolved?; How plants think.
item.itunes:subtitle: Renowned paleo-anthropologist Dean Falk on how the evolution of our brains led to the emergence of language, music, analytical thinking, and warfare in humans. Plant biologist Professor Ottoline Leyser explains how plants manage to survive and thrive without a brain.
item.description: Renowned paleo-anthropologist Dean Falk on how the evolution of our brains led to the emergence of language, music, analytical thinking, and warfare in humans. Plant biologist Professor Ottoline Leyser explains how plants manage to survive and thrive without a brain.

media:group.media:description: How do plants make life and death decisions

item.title: Dr Lynn Arnold AO joins Phillip for a chat
item.itunes:subtitle: The Honourable Reverend Dr Lynn Arnold AO has one of those names that tells you immediately – he’s done a few things. He’s been busy. You don’t get that many prefixes and suffixes without burning the midnight oil.
item.description: The Honourable Reverend Dr Lynn Arnold AO has one of those names that tells you immediately – he’s done a few things. He’s been busy. You don’t get that many prefixes and suffixes without burning the midnight oil.

item.title: Mary Anning; How the Earth shapes our destinies
item.itunes:subtitle: How did a 19th-century English working-class woman with no formal education end up becoming one of the most influential fossilists of all time? We explore the impact of ice, wind and plate tectonics on who we are today.
item.description: How did a 19th-century English working-class woman with no formal education end up becoming one of the most influential fossilists of all time? We explore the impact of ice, wind and plate tectonics on who we are today.

item.title: Eva Cox
item.itunes:subtitle: Eva Cox on life, her 1995 Boyer lectures and what's next.
item.description: Eva Cox on life, her 1995 Boyer lectures and what's next.

media:group.media:description: Eva Cox and Phillip Adams in the Late Night Live studio.

item.title: Was 2019 a good year for comedy?
item.itunes:subtitle: A panel of eminent satirists canvasses the comedy fodder offered up in the past year.
item.description: A panel of eminent satirists canvasses the comedy fodder offered up in the past year.

media:group.media:description: Standing, from left: Phillip Adams, Alice Fraser, Dan Ilic, Cathy Wilcox. Token appearance by Andy Matthews

item.title: Trump's apocalypse and Ireland in 1922
item.itunes:subtitle: Are the evangelical supporters of Trump hoping he will bring on the apocalypse and with Brexit remaining an ongoing issue, what can we learn from the Irish Civil War of 1922.
item.description: Are the evangelical supporters of Trump hoping he will bring on the apocalypse and with Brexit remaining an ongoing issue, what can we learn from the Irish Civil War of 1922.

media:group.media:description: General Michael Collins leaves a Requiem service held at Portobello Barracks, Dublin. August 1922. Not long before his assassination by Anti-Treaty IRA.

item.title: Bruce Shapiro and Australia in 1956
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce Shapiro wraps up the year and Nick Richardson explains the significance of 1956 in Australia's history.
item.description: Bruce Shapiro wraps up the year and Nick Richardson explains the significance of 1956 in Australia's history.

item.title: Laura Tingle; Wikileaks; Canberra's view on Julian Assange
item.itunes:subtitle: A week of machismo and masochism as the Prime Minister fights to save the political career of his Energy Minister, Angus Taylor. Kristinn Hrafnsson explains why journalists should care about what happens to Julian Assange.
item.description: A week of machismo and masochism as the Prime Minister fights to save the political career of his Energy Minister, Angus Taylor. Kristinn Hrafnsson explains why journalists should care about what happens to Julian Assange.

item.title: Daniel McCarthy's Washington update and Vale Clive James
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel McCarthy explores what effects the impeachment proceedings are having on voter sentiment and we commemorate Clive James. In an interview with Phillip in 2006, the late raconteur reveals his love of the tango, Japanese culture and Peter Sellers.
item.description: Daniel McCarthy explores what effects the impeachment proceedings are having on voter sentiment and we commemorate Clive James. In an interview with Phillip in 2006, the late raconteur reveals his love of the tango, Japanese culture and Peter Sellers.

item.title: Tories in trouble with Twitter; Trump and right wing media; time to bring Russia in from the Cold?
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Dunt wraps up the year in UK politics as the Brexit election looms.
item.description: Ian Dunt wraps up the year in UK politics as the Brexit election looms.

item.title: Bruce Shapiro and Christopher Tughendhat
item.itunes:subtitle: News from America with Bruce Shapiro and the history of Britain in books.
item.description: News from America with Bruce Shapiro and the history of Britain in books.

item.title: Laura Tingle; Westpac's money laundering scandal; Dreaming under Hitler
item.itunes:subtitle: It was China, China, China in parliament today. Failure at controlling money laundering doesn't only damage Westpac managers, it hurts small communities throughout Asia and the Pacific who have no access to banking services. After Hitler came to power in 1933, Jewish journalist Charlotte Beradt began collecting the dreams of her fellow Berliners. Her work provides a unique insight into the effect authoritarian regimes have on unconscious thoughts
item.description: It was China, China, China in parliament today. Failure at controlling money laundering doesn't only damage Westpac managers, it hurts small communities throughout Asia and the Pacific who have no access to banking services. After Hitler came to power in 1933, Jewish journalist Charlotte Beradt began collecting the dreams of her fellow Berliners. Her work provides a unique insight into the effect authoritarian regimes have on unconscious thoughts

item.title: The politics behind the Christchurch massacre and the history of Venus
item.itunes:subtitle: Journalist Jeff Sparrow traces the fascist roots of the Christchurch massacre and British historian Bettany Hughes explores the darker side of the goddess Venus.
item.description: Journalist Jeff Sparrow traces the fascist roots of the Christchurch massacre and British historian Bettany Hughes explores the darker side of the goddess Venus.

item.title: Asbestos in Asia, Alexander von Humboldt and vale Colin Tatz
item.itunes:subtitle: Asbestos on the rise in Asia, who was Alexander von Humboldt and vale Colin Tatz
item.description: Asbestos on the rise in Asia, who was Alexander von Humboldt and vale Colin Tatz

item.title: 19 November 2019
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce Shapiro on Trump's impeachment hearings; Google's obsession with your health; and the forest that will become books to fill a library - in the year 2114.
item.description: Bruce Shapiro on Trump's impeachment hearings; Google's obsession with your health; and the forest that will become books to fill a library - in the year 2114.

item.title: The adventures of Di Morrissey
item.itunes:subtitle: Di Morrissey has come full circle coming back to her birth place and journalistic roots.
item.description: Di Morrissey has come full circle coming back to her birth place and journalistic roots.

item.title: Geoffrey Robertson on museums of plunder and LNL Revisited: Geraldine Brooks
item.itunes:subtitle: Geoffrey Robertson discusses why the British Museum should "wash its hands of blood" and return the Elgin marbles, the Benin bronzes and "other pilfered cultural property.”
item.description: Geoffrey Robertson discusses why the British Museum should "wash its hands of blood" and return the Elgin marbles, the Benin bronzes and "other pilfered cultural property.”

item.title: Ian Dunt's UK, climate change as a security threat and women at war
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Dunt discusses how political parties in the UK are gearing up for the December 12 election, Danish academic Ole Wæver explains how political response to climate change could threaten democracy and Simon Parkin on the ingenious young British women who helped turn back Nazi U-boats in World War Two.
item.description: Ian Dunt discusses how political parties in the UK are gearing up for the December 12 election, Danish academic Ole Wæver explains how political response to climate change could threaten democracy and Simon Parkin on the ingenious young British women who helped turn back Nazi U-boats in World War Two.

item.title: Bruce Shapiro on US politics, Spain back to the polls, and understanding animals
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce discusses the emergence of Michael Bloomberg for the Democrats, and other matters. Spain keeps on heading back to the polls. And a philosopher's take on the human/animal connection.
item.description: Bruce discusses the emergence of Michael Bloomberg for the Democrats, and other matters. Spain keeps on heading back to the polls. And a philosopher's take on the human/animal connection.

item.title: Laura Tingle; Bougainville Independence referendum; History of Climate Science
item.itunes:subtitle: Labor's election post-mortem. The referendum on independence for Bougainville starts on 23 November, what are the options for the future?
item.description: Labor's election post-mortem. The referendum on independence for Bougainville starts on 23 November, what are the options for the future?

item.title: US update, Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and the Poisoner's Handbook
item.itunes:subtitle: Daniel McCarthy brings us an update on the gubernatorial elections in the US, historian Elizabeth Leake on what role the CIA played in the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and we revisit a classic from the LNL archives: Deborah Blum on the invention of modern forensic medicine.
item.description: Daniel McCarthy brings us an update on the gubernatorial elections in the US, historian Elizabeth Leake on what role the CIA played in the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and we revisit a classic from the LNL archives: Deborah Blum on the invention of modern forensic medicine.

item.title: Aged care and Charles Massy
item.itunes:subtitle: Aged care workers tell their story, as does 5th generation farmer Charles Massy.
item.description: Aged care workers tell their story, as does 5th generation farmer Charles Massy.

item.itunes:subtitle: An impeachment update, the source of Chile's unrest and Australia's islands reviewed
item.description: An impeachment update, the source of Chile's unrest and Australia's islands reviewed

item.title: Laura Tingle ;Health and Climate Change; The Woman behind the first fairy tale
item.itunes:subtitle: Quiet Australians and noisy minorities. The World Health Organisation has declared climate change to be "the most significant threat of the 21st century." What impact is it having on Australians' health?
item.description: Quiet Australians and noisy minorities. The World Health Organisation has declared climate change to be "the most significant threat of the 21st century." What impact is it having on Australians' health?

item.description: The history and future of religion and the history and future of Europe

item.title: Ian Dunt's UK, People Smuggling & Mosquitoes
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Dunt discusses the UK's upcoming December election, we look at the increasing risks of undocumented migration and we meet the most dangerous animal in the world, the mosquito.
item.description: Ian Dunt discusses the UK's upcoming December election, we look at the increasing risks of undocumented migration and we meet the most dangerous animal in the world, the mosquito.

item.title: Report from America, France and the hijab, Naomi Klein
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce Shapiro on the latest from the impeachment hearings, John Litchfield on the latest controversy surrounding the hijab in France, and Naomi Klein outlines the case for a green new deal.
item.description: Bruce Shapiro on the latest from the impeachment hearings, John Litchfield on the latest controversy surrounding the hijab in France, and Naomi Klein outlines the case for a green new deal.

item.title: Canberra Capers; Facial Recognition; George Seddon's legacy
item.itunes:subtitle: Shifting the goal posts in Canberra. Is facial recognition technology creating a dangerous mass surveillance system. Remembering George Seddon, an extraordinary polymath who radically rethought our relationship with the environment.
item.description: Shifting the goal posts in Canberra. Is facial recognition technology creating a dangerous mass surveillance system. Remembering George Seddon, an extraordinary polymath who radically rethought our relationship with the environment.

item.title: Dan McCarthy's America, fake news in Asia and Dr Claire Weekes
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan McCarthy on Republicans storming the impeachment inquiry, how fake news is threatening democracy in South East Asia and Judith Hoare celebrates the pioneering Australian doctor who cracked the anxiety code.
item.description: Dan McCarthy on Republicans storming the impeachment inquiry, how fake news is threatening democracy in South East Asia and Judith Hoare celebrates the pioneering Australian doctor who cracked the anxiety code.

item.title: Bruce Shapiro on US politics; highway through the Amazon; crabs and conflict

item.description: Bruce Shapiro on two bizarre press conferences, and more. President Bolsonaro is rebuilding a highway through the Amazon. And what crabs can tell us about when conflict is necessary

item.title: US update, Turkey's Syria offensive and ISIS brides
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce mulls over the Columbus Day debate and brings us the latest on the Impeachment inquiry, Joost Hiltermann updates us on Turkey's military offensive in northern Syria and the Iranian-American journalist Azadeh Moaveni discusses the fate of the young women who joined Islamic State.
item.description: Bruce mulls over the Columbus Day debate and brings us the latest on the Impeachment inquiry, Joost Hiltermann updates us on Turkey's military offensive in northern Syria and the Iranian-American journalist Azadeh Moaveni discusses the fate of the young women who joined Islamic State.

item.description: Katharine Murphy with the latest from Canberra, David Uren on the role of ASIO in foreign investment decisions and Jung Chang on the Soong sisters

item.title: Cyber security conference speakers dumped. US prisoners and the right to read. Maps and memories in the Middle East
item.itunes:subtitle: NSA whistle blower Thomas Drake and academic Suelette Dreyfus reflect on free speech and why they were disinvited to a recent cyber security conference.
item.description: NSA whistle blower Thomas Drake and academic Suelette Dreyfus reflect on free speech and why they were disinvited to a recent cyber security conference.

item.title: LNL Wednesday 9th October
item.itunes:subtitle: Some of the Hong Kong protest leaders have now said violence is their only option. We get an update on how the divisions in Hong Kong are likely to pan out.
item.description: Some of the Hong Kong protest leaders have now said violence is their only option. We get an update on how the divisions in Hong Kong are likely to pan out.

item.title: Bruce Shapiro on US politics; the Iraqi protests; Utopia the TV series
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce Shapiro on the new Supreme Court, the second whistleblower and Trump's surprising foreign policy move.

item.title: Impeachment, Afghanistan elections and mudlarking
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan McCarthy on the campaign to impeach President Trump. Election observer Srinjoy Bose and the latest from Afghanistan and amateur archaeologist Lara Miallem goes mudlarking on the banks of the river Thames.
item.description: Dan McCarthy on the campaign to impeach President Trump. Election observer Srinjoy Bose and the latest from Afghanistan and amateur archaeologist Lara Miallem goes mudlarking on the banks of the river Thames.

item.title: Ian Dunt's UK; Where power stops; How charts lie
item.itunes:subtitle: Ian Dunt brings us the latest news from the UK including Boris Johnson's 'final' Brexit offer and the highs and lows of the Conservative Party conference. In the age of populism what makes and destroys a political leader.
item.description: Ian Dunt brings us the latest news from the UK including Boris Johnson's 'final' Brexit offer and the highs and lows of the Conservative Party conference. In the age of populism what makes and destroys a political leader.

item.title: Impeachment scandal, the Ukrainian affair and Penny Wong bio
item.itunes:subtitle: Bruce brings us the latest on the impeachment scandal and President Trump's request for Australian help in investigating the Mueller inquiry, Michael Colborne discusses the fall-out from the Trump-Zelensky phone call and Margaret Simons explains how she came to write the first-ever biography of Penny Wong.
item.description: Bruce brings us the latest on the impeachment scandal and President Trump's request for Australian help in investigating the Mueller inquiry, Michael Colborne discusses the fall-out from the Trump-Zelensky phone call and Margaret Simons explains how she came to write the first-ever biography of Penny Wong.

item.title: Canberra Politics; Hate and Health; Black Holes
item.itunes:subtitle: Anxiety about Climate change policy dominates national politics. We spend billions on health care but is it making us any healthier? What are black holes and wormholes?
item.description: Anxiety about Climate change policy dominates national politics. We spend billions on health care but is it making us any healthier? What are black holes and wormholes?

item.title: A portrait of Gillian Triggs, human rights defender
item.itunes:subtitle: Gillian Triggs explains where her passion for human rights came from.
item.description: Gillian Triggs explains where her passion for human rights came from.
